name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-chlorophenyl)furan-2-yl]-1-(5-methylfuran-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1176

name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-chlorophenyl)furan-2-yl]-1-(5-methylfuran-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1176
Reason: The target compound has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic structure for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The influences from each functional group are approximated as follows: Chlorophenyl group introduces significant rigidity and has strong intermolecular attractions due to the chlorine, which might add around +75 °C. Each furan ring might contribute +15 °C due to its aromatic nature and planarity. The methyl group adds some steric bulk, which may contribute +5 °C. The prop-2-en-1-one group contributes with additional rigidity and polar C=O bond, adding roughly +30°C. Combining these estimations: 5.5°C (benzene base) + 75°C (chlorophenyl) + 30°C (two furan rings) + 5°C (methyl) + 30°C (prop-2-en-1-one group) = 145.5 °C.

name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-chlorophenyl)furan-2-yl]-1-(5-methylfuran-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1176
Reason: The compound in question has a multitude of functional groups that affect its melting point. Starting from benzene with a melting point of 5.5 °C, we evaluate the impact of each substituent. The chlorophenyl group, with its high electronegativity and capacity to engage in strong intermolecular interactions, particularly dipole-dipole interactions, can substantially increase the melting point – estimated addition of +80 °C due to these effects and increased molecular rigidity. Furan rings are aromatic and contribute to planarity and stability of the molecule; each furan ring could add roughly +20 °C due to the π-π stacking and possible H-bonding. The methyl group attached to one of the furan rings possibly makes the molecule slightly more bulky, yet allows for some additional van der Waals interactions, estimated to increase the point by +5 °C. The prop-2-en-1-one structure incorporates an α,β-unsaturated carbonyl which creates both a rigid planar system and possible hydrogen bonding, adding about +35 °C to the melting point. When we sum these adjustments: 5.5 °C (basis of benzene) + 80 °C (chlorophenyl group) + 40 °C (two furan rings) + 5 °C (methyl group) + 35 °C (prop-2-en-1-one), we get a predicted melting point of 165.5 °C.
